timeline.bodyText: Little improvement: please rephrase this message. Also, the existing way of selecting policy does the logging more elegantly (It only log at most once).
timeline.author: voidzcy

timeline.bodyText: nit: may not want to put white space after \n. Apply to other places as well.
timeline.author: voidzcy

timeline.bodyText: Why not this(LoadBalancerRegistry.getDefaultRegistry()) and make lbRegistry non-null? Then you do not need the method loadBalancerRegistry().
timeline.author: voidzcy

timeline.bodyText:
Little improvement: although I am not an opponent for writing giant methods, this one seems to be too big to read. This can be elegantly split into two helper methods: one for parsing route and one for parsing action. Each one returns a list or a map and throws exception.
I am also fine if you just leave it as is.
timeline.author: voidzcy

replies.bodyText: It's kind of not easy because the current code eagerly returns a ConfigOrError whenever it fails.
replies.author: dapengzhang0

timeline.bodyText:
s/methodName/method_name/g
Error message for input data, not implementation details.
timeline.author: voidzcy

timeline.bodyText: nit: delete redundant empty line. Check other places.
timeline.author: voidzcy
voidzcy
voidzcy

timeline.bodyText:
Use XdsLogger? Whatever, can leave it as is and improve as things being stabilized.
Update: don't need to change it, just leave it as is. Configuring log handler io.grpc.xds can still include this logger.
timeline.author: voidzcy

timeline.bodyText: I think we should define a ParsedConfig class with policyName and config fields, similar to LbConfig. This could be useful for all hierarchical LB configs.
timeline.author: voidzcy

replies.bodyText: Yes, that is also my plan, currently we have AutoConfiguredLoadBalancerFactory.PolicySelection which basically is the ParsedConfig. It has a deprecated field rawConfig just for the backward compatibility in legacy usecase.
replies.author: dapengzhang0

replies.bodyText: Also, defining types with name ChildXXX doesn't sound good, unless it's an internal implementation (private) or locally used. "Child" is meaningful only in the context of one policy's internal implementation.
replies.author: voidzcy
